commentBody: A guard, a barber, a chef and a miner walk into a bar...

Much easier than yesterday. ASPERSE is a new word to me. So new that I was convinced I had a crossing wrong until I got the Gold Star.

Also, shout out to 1A on the Mini. That's an all time favorite clue right there

Okay, Wordplayers in the Durham (-ish) area are looking forward to lunch on July 15--in Greensboro this year. If you're interested and not already known to the Durham-Wordplay group, send us an email at crosswordgrrl at gmail.com. We're looking forward to an entertaining get-together!
üé∂üéµ A MINERRRRRRRR üéµüé∂

After an exam, students have grade expectations.

(And the test is history.)

A PLUS WORK on this one, Jesse. And what a fun one this was to reach my four year streak!! ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è HANNA BARBERA brought back so many memories of my favorite childhood cartoons. DOPAMINE RUSH indeed. PASTA over Gordon RAMSAY made me chuckle. 

Thank you, Jesse.

A guard, a barber, a chef, and a miner walk into a puzzle. The barber is thrilled to find the MOHAWKS right away. The chef leaves in a huff because RAMSAY was already sitting there. The guard MAKES PEACE among some tipsy patrons. The miner looks around for the ORE - it‚Äôs almost always there - and, not finding it, says ‚ÄúWhat is this, a joke?‚Äù

(Hi, Steve L, you read my mind!)
Sorry, but baptisms don‚Äôt take place at altars. They‚Äôre done in a baptismal font or pool, or in a river, depending on the church involved.

Ok, starting with a gripe on the over use of sac(s) in crosswords lately. Saw Scooby clue ooo where are you? And immediately went to Hanna Barbera. Love Master Chef and Next Level Chef but wasn‚Äôt sure if Ramsay wasn‚Äôt Ramsey. Liked the crossing of spambot and sensor.
Finally, as an English teacher on summer vacation I cringe at any reference to grades even in themes, but enjoyed learning a different version of aspersion.

Food related: 
Cash cow
Gravy Train
Bread & butter

And or for Dutch frisians, to make one‚Äôs sandwich ‚Äî ‚Äú goede boterham verdienen.‚Äù

RANDO is millennial slang‚Äôs greatest gift to our language. The word just tickles me pink. 

I SPED through this as if Jesse Guzman were sitting on my shoulder, whispering the answers before I even had the chance to fully read the clues. (Also, I finally put on my new reading glasses.) Sometimes a puzzle just goes like that and it‚Äôs a DOPAMINE RUSH not unlike still running a 7-minute mile for those of us who missed the Millennial bracket cutoff by a couple of years. TRU THIS. (Admitting that with my new glasses on I can now actually *see* the puzzle drains said dopamine faster than a hot tub with a submersible pump.)

On that note, my running shoes are calling my name. Have a good one, y‚Äôall!

Re the XWstats website, which I assume attracts the crossword cognoscenti. What a humbling website üòÇ. (Can‚Äôt decide‚Äîdoes the period go before or after the emoji?) Man, you people are FAST solvers. I complete this puzzle in 7 minutes and think that‚Äôs pretty decent. Not a personal record or anything, but zippy. Check XWstats and see the mean solving time is under 6 minutes!

So now my new goal is to someday complete a puzzle below the mean time. A guy can dream!

This was much more pleasant than yesterday's grid, and I filled it 15% faster. As with most easy puzzles, I ignored the theme during the solve, but I didn't mind it when it emerged at the end - most themes that are not a set of groaners are OK with me.

I like it when a puzzle will help me remember something new that I learned from a recent one. Only a few weeks ago I learned coins may be found in American sofas. Perhaps because Polish people usually change from street to home clothes as soon as they come in, coins don't accumulate in our sofas. For decades now I've been finding it very strange how Americans (on tv, anyway) will walk around their homes in street shoes, and even put them up on cushioned furniture... That's one of a Pole's biggest hygienic no-nos - hygiene is among the earliest topics of our education.

I realized I didn't know how to spell the animation studio. I started putting in Hannah Barbera... And ran out of room with one letter to go. I waited for crosses to see what was wrong. Oooh, it's HANNA! Like the American climber Ben Hanna rather than Hannah Meul the German climber ü§£

I also wanted RAMSeY rather than RAMSAY, but an alter is not a thing, is it.

Interestingly, kapusta (cabbage) is Polish slang for money, too. According to one online theory, it is probably a mistaken loan (of sorts) from German. In German, Kohle (coal) may mean money, which sounds similar to Kohl (cabbage). A mistranslation may have occured on loaning the term.

9 minutes, new PB for a Tuesday. 
However‚Ä¶ wheels don‚Äôt have ‚Äòends‚Äô üòÖ
It seems the Monday and Tuesday puzzles got switched this week.
Can someone explain CLASH at 28A? I thought colors opposite each other on the color wheel were complimentary?

baptisms do not occur at the altar - they are almost always at the front of the church (i.e. opposite the altar) to symbolise the entry of the person (whether infant, child or adult) into the life of the church
This one took me much longer than a usual Tuesday for some reason, but I‚Äôm not complaining. More puzzle time = more joy!
A fun and breezy solving experience. Kudos to the constructor.

Re Tuesday July 8th - Clue for 11 Down - baptisms do NOT happen at this place - they happen at the font, which is traditionally located near the main door of the church. This inaccuracy threw me off for a while! 

(I realise baptists etc don‚Äôt have fonts, but then they don‚Äôt have answer to 11 downs either)
Didn't get the gimmick until after I solved it but it wasn't bad. :)
What a fun Tuesday puzzle, I‚Äôm glad your Dad approved it, Jesse.

I enjoyed solving your puzzle, Jesse.
I enjoyed your column and picture choice, Sam. 
So far, so good.

With all the talk of solving times I tried my hand at a speed run‚Äîbut I have to say it left me feeling a bit flat. Reading the column afterwards made me feel that I had missed half the fun. SPAMBOT, ASPERSE, and MOHAWK all filled on crosses, so I never had the DOPAMINE RUSH of feeling those pennies drop. Tomorrow, I‚Äôm going back to the leisurely solve over coffee.

Shouldn't 14 across solve as "edgy"? 

Unexpectedly challenging for a Tuesday. Good one.

Sam, that opener was spot-on.
Hire purpose‚Ä¶ 
Nailed it.

Nice one Jesse. 
Smooth as silk.

Have a delightful Tuesday all.

All of this hoo-ha about baptisms taking place at the altar versus the font or baptistery (a dedicated structure, annexed or adjacent to the main church, and which itself may contain an altar) got me thinking: perhaps there should be a place or structure within a church dedicated to the marriage rite. I propose it be called the "vinctery." A beautiful scene from a beautiful movie: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u9cCcGIstCw Twice my time for a typical Tuesday.
Much too hard for Tuesday.  Tuesday is supposed to be easy.   I still don't get the circled letters even with the explanation.    Save the showing off for Thursday, Friday, Saturday.
Fun puzzle, cute & clever theme, perfect Tuesday - thanks Jesse!

I‚Äôm very jet lagged so that may be why this felt hard for a Tuesday. I tried to make WarnerBros fit for way too long! And I‚Äôm not happy about the cluing for EDGE, but otherwise, this was a fun one.

If someone who cooks is a cook, 
then is a dress alterationist AHEM ?

And of course a librarian is ASH.

Fun puzzle. Not a job to fill.

The clue for 11 down has really altared the course of the comments today.  As someone who hasn't gone to church regularly since my parents made me back in 1970 or so, the clue, accurate or not, led me easily to the answer.

Cute theme and an enjoyable Tuesday workout. The only real slow-down was DOPAMINERUSH. That's a completely unfamiliar term for me and had me re-checking the crosses as I filled it in. And... once I worked out the reveal it was a lot of fun to go back and look at the theme answers until it finally dawned on me. 

A couple of puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

....

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Two NYT puzzles in a week and a half ‚Äì Bravo!  
‚Ä¢	My funny solving moment: Entering HEED for [Obedience class command], then picturing someone with a dog, commanding them to ‚ÄúHeed!  Heed!‚Äù
‚Ä¢	What a great idea for a theme!  Never done before. I imagine Jesse coming across the phrase A-PLUS WORK, and that crossword mind immediately click, click,clicking.
‚Ä¢	I like how [Blue expanse] could either be SEA or SKY.  I wonder how many immediately slapped in SKY as I did.
‚Ä¢	Erik Agard, whose name sits atop so many quality puzzles, came so close to being embedded in this one at LAGUARDIA.
‚Ä¢	DOPAMINE RUSH just lights the whole grid up; appropriately crossed by SHEEN.
‚Ä¢	With a Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Tuesday, Jesse can become only the second constructor to hit the cycle (a puzzle for every day of the week) in his first seven puzzles.  Go for it!

Jesse, four puzzles in, IMO, you‚Äôve established that you‚Äôre a first-rate constructor, a PLAYA.  This was a gem -- thank you !
Almost as fun as a Thursday! A plus!

A summary of my experience today: He STARES at the filled grid, unfamiliar with the TERM  TRU THIS and unable to SPELL RAMSAY correctly. He begins to ASPERSE (the constructor, the editorial team, the current generation in general), and then realizes that it's TRUTH IS, and that vows are not exchanged at an ALTER.

Solid Tuesday puzzle. Not an enthralling theme, but adequate in quantity and quality. Especially if one knows HANNABARBERA.
Fun Tuesday solve! Thank you!
Drew a blank on John ROLFE and got my RUSH's mixed up so that bottom section came hard (hint, it's not Smith and not adrenaline).  Nice one.  Dad has good judgement.

Quite tough for a Tuesday. Got hung up for so long in the SW I considered looking something up just so I could finish but thought, ‚ÄúNope. Not on a Tuesday.‚Äù Was able to hack my way through, but finished about 40% above my average time, so I‚Äôd give myself a C-minus‚Ä¶passing since I finished with no help, but just barely passing.

Let's hope we don't get another visit from the Late-Blooming Commentator who left the last Comment yesterday....  Congrats to the ever-vigilant Emus....Not.

Oh, the puzzle.....is this a list of jobs they threaten  you with if you don't go to college?  (Not every CHEF is a Gordon RAMSAY or Emeril, plus--just as Bill from Detroit--it's a demanding line of work.)  

OTTAWA....reminded me of the movie "Canadian Bacon"....I think we need to see that again.  Could use a few laughs!  (John Candy insisting that Toronto is the capital....)

57A had me stumped...because I needed to clean my glasses, had taken out my first guess at 46A --ADRENrats-- and thought that 4th letter was still an R due to incomplete erasure...so I had MAKES REA-E which had me baffled....What a DOPA!

All's well that ends well.
Looks like I‚Äôm the first to mention the weevil pun in the movie ‚ÄúMaster and Commander.‚Äù
A PLUS WORK? Really?

BREAD, of course, is another food that means money. I wish I hadn't been so slow to solve this one when I need to be packing for my own upcoming DOPAMINE RUSH at amusement park... better if I had SPED through. Alas!

Okay, yesterday I posted a Tommy Boy clip in response to a comment about cow tipping. Today's mention of BEES in the puzzle reminds me that I'm legally bound to post or discuss this clip every time the topic comes up. üòÇ https://youtu.be/TPFlKJp5jXU?si=S3xAsVEMited22UN A little trick my dad taught me!
I would like to say this was pretty much a Perfect Puzzle for a Tuesday.

When will the Dice/Domino game be off beta and back?  I really enjoyed it.  Please direct me to the correct place to ask this question if this is the wrong one.  I confess I haven‚Äôt a clue although I love playing all the rest of the games.  Thank you to all of you with a clue.

Well, it‚Äôs going to be one of those weeks. I struggled a tad yesterday, I struggled again today. Can‚Äôt wait for Thursday.

To be clear; this is on me, not the puzzle. I think the heat is melting my brain. I‚Äôm British. I‚Äôm not made for sunshine and blue skies. 

I did get the theme with GUARD and BARBER snuck in the answers, but slightly fell off the cliff with the rest. 
Despite using an iPad I couldn‚Äôt understand MACOS for ages. *slaps forehead*.

Not a fan of the sweary man. He‚Äôs an unpleasant chap. Give me Nigella any day. 

Onwards, hoping my brain reactivates tomorrow.

Where do baptisms take¬†place?¬† This seems to be a topic of discussion today, with many people assuming that their personal experience can be universalized into a Christian law. Here's what I think: Some cathedrals have buildings dedicated to the practice.¬† The Florence Baptistery is well-known, just next to the city's Duomo, and famed for its bronze doors.¬† Pisa has an even more ornate Baptistery (near its famous "leaning tower" which is the cathedral's campanile or bell-tower). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Baptistery https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pisa_Baptistery Other large churches have dedicated baptismal fonts, usually built into a side chapel so as not to interfere with the other church rituals. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baptismal_font Some churches have only a portable baptismal font, which is merely a good-sized basin and a stand.¬† These can be taken out whenever needed and stored away when not¬†in use.¬† These fonts can be placed anywhere in a church, but most commonly they would be used at the ALTAR. https://inhisname.com/collections/baptismal-fonts?srsltid=AfmBOopG44wRy36W57ZInMcdQlfGhOP1oSH1fMD-GYq653H6FP2SsFaM Of¬†course, some Baptists like to perform their baptisms in a nearby river, if one is available. There's a well-known scene in the movie "O Brother, Where Art Thou?" that shows a wonderful example. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VC5eSSaVGcE Anyone care to add to this essay, or can we put the question to rest?

I‚Äôm sorry, but‚Ä¶.

Cabbage, bacon, cheddar?????????? 

These are slang words for money??? Seriously? Is this an American thing? If so, I guess I‚Äôll have to swallow it, as usual, but as a mother tongue English speaking Brit, I am incredulous. What else is ‚Äúmoney‚Äù? 

‚ÄúHey Mom, I‚Äôm going to the store, can I take some sausages out of your purse? I looked in dad‚Äôs wallet but he doesn‚Äôt have any elephants. He spent all his cucumbers at the mall yesterday ‚Äú

See how ridiculous this sounds?

Didn‚Äôt really use the theme until I solved it but had an error. Once I figured it out I was able to change LeGUARDIA to LAGUARDIA.  Silly northwesterner. 

Cute little theme. :-)
My reaction to 45 across was: Yum! That sounds like my kind of pastry.

Hi! Hope everyone had a good July 4th weekend. I was somewhere without the internet until Saturday night(our own fault not just turning the modem off and on:) and we made a few calls to emailers we had to answer but otherwise I didn‚Äôt miss it however the Saturday and Sunday puzzles looked tough at first glance I have to say! I enjoyed today‚Äôs and got it under 15‚Äù except some flyspecking! 
Thanks to the constructor.

What a fun puzzle. A bit crunchy -- just right for a Tuesday. The words I didn't know could eventually be filled in by the crosses. Did put in SOFA, then erased it, but it turned out to be right. Yes, a lot of synonyms for money are  words for food (yum). But, as well as MOOLAH, there is simoleons, and probably many other non-food words.

The theme was clever and delightful. Bravo, Jesse Guzman!
A tough Tuesday for me, for whatever reason.
After a tough Monday...a tough Tuesday. Finished in 13 minutes again, like yesterday. Hoping for an easy Wednesday!
Flew through this one and finished 30 seconds off my PB. A nice "get-right" puzzle after yesterday
I could not parse MACOS as Mac OS for a ridiculously long time. I kept thinking, "They named it after sharks??? How do I not know this? Where have I been?"
Fantastic puzzle. Crosses helped solve words or clues I didn't know. The "A-HA!" moment when getting the revealer was also great.
Another euphemism for money:  kale. Much like cabbage, but less edible!
Just one of those days where you almost break your streak because your typed ALTER instead of ALTAR.
Nice little 46A for a Tuesday. Not my best time, but I am consistently bringing down my average.
This was fun, but‚Ä¶.. Color wheels (any kind of wheels), don‚Äôt have opposite ends. They have opposite sides‚Ä¶
As is often the case, the NYT claims I missed a word, but I didn't. This happens a lot to me. Needs fixing.
Good puzzle but "A plus job" would have been a bit better revealer.
58A made me laugh. There‚Äôs a meme out there somewhere about how this coin collection pays a spider‚Äôs rent.

Took me quite some time to see the theme. Probably would have helped if I‚Äôd looked at the revealer sooner. As it was I hopped all over. It was very satisfying when I finally got it, and more challenging than usual (for me) on a Tuesday. Thanks Daniel Raymon.

24 Across is wrong. There are Semitic languages, there is an Afro-Semitic language group, but there are no Semitic people. Ethnicity is not genetics and neither ethnicity nor genetics are language. People get confused because the  world "antisemitic" was invented to mean hatred of Jews. But that was the 19th century racist notion that ethnicity and language and race were connected. Calling Jews and Arabs Semites is the logic Germans used to call themselves Aryans.
Nice puzzle! :)
A crossover episode! Connections makes a brief appearance in the Crossword. This was fun!
An A plus work by the constructor.   Though I wouldn‚Äôt have recognized the theme without the article.
nice puzzle but too bad that REALLY BAD IDEA doesn't fit 27A

I immediately entered John smith as the Pocahontas answer (thanks Disney version) and was shocked to realise that wasn‚Äôt his real name!! (From NZ where we aren‚Äôt taught Native American history in school)

I know the punk hairstyle as ‚ÄòMohican‚Äô. I wonder why it‚Äôs different.

Would have been nice to have Seville in the puzzle somewhere, for fans of 49A.

@Bonnie Nestor 
Came here to say this, too! The clue threw me a bit; weddings don't take place at the altar, either.

For no good reason, my long reply was withheld.

Polish Catholic weddings sure do take place at the altar. Baptisms, too, apparently (I had to look the latter up as I've never seen one live).
@Bonnie Nestor The Baptism scene in the Godfather. Isn't that at an altar?
@Swift O yes they do. 100% Where else do people marry in a church?

@Andrzej Not just Polish Catholics. Italian and Irish ones too. At least in New York City. All the ones I've been to are at the altar. The Christenings, which is how we refer to baptisms are at the font, which is situated to the side of the altar. Maybe Guzman is a Catholic? I did go to an Episcopalian wedding and that was at the altar too.

@Andrzej See my above. Every single Catholic wedding and Christening were by the altar. The baptismal font is to the side of the author. I'm talking people of Italian, Polish, Ukrainian, German, and Irish extraction. Ditto Episcopalian wedding. Where ELSE would a person get married unless it was outdoors or under a chupah. I've never seen a Muslim one. Has anyone seen that?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Mosques don't have altars, do they?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

A chupah is usually at the altar in a synagogue, too. Unless it's outside :)

@Bonnie Nestor

Presbyterians get baptized 
and married at the altar,
or the raised, front area of the sanctuary.

That‚Äôs all I got.

@CCNY
Presbyterians, in Scotland anyway, don‚Äôt have an alter. Anything the Catholics had was rejected. No priests or confession, or statues, pictures, holy water, no kneeling, vestments, catechism or set prayers, (except for the Lord‚Äôs Prayer), the list goes on. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs the same for the USA. 

There was a rhyme we knew as children, ‚ÄúPresbies‚Äù mocking ‚ÄúPiscies‚Äù (Episcopalians) and their catechism:
Piscie, Piscie, bow and bend
On your knees and up again. 
Presbie, Presbie dinna (do not) bend
Sit yourself on man‚Äôs chief end.

@Bonnie Nestor
Traditionally, baptismal fonts were in the entrance to the church, but not on the altar. The idea was that one had to be baptized before they could ‚Äúenter‚Äù the church. As with most things traditional, many churches have evolved to move the baptismal font to the altar. More picturesque for photos and less walking for the clergy. :-)

@Brad

Chips
Kale
Roll

@Brad

I'm clueless.  What are we doing here?

Lettuce 
Bread

@Brad
It‚Äôs not really a sandwich. A broodje is a sandwich. Boterham is more like a single slice of bread with butter, like in the English expression, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs his bread and butter‚Äù.

@Sam Lyons
I parsed 4D as TRUTH IS, but your way works, too.

@Heidi The irony here is that I‚Äôm totally with you. Ever-faster is a ruinous philosophy in so many ways. And it‚Äôs certainly not the focus of my crossword experience, which I often do with leisure over a meal, etc. But sometimes for whatever reason I do one quickly, or at least what I thought was quickly‚Ä¶ üòÇ
@HeathieJ Why so much drinking?

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight

Because HeathieJ enjoys it?

@Aaron Teasdale I am awed by the speed at which some can solve the puzzles.  I play for speed only on Monday puzzles, but even when every answer comes to me immediately, I find it physically impossible to key in all the letters (I use the app) in less than double the time some some solvers claim for solving the same puzzle.
@Heidi This ‚òùÔ∏è

@Andrzej

Thank you!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Stay away from that diet Coke!  That stuff'll kill you,....and we need you around here.

@Heidi I'm with you.  I do sometimes enjoy getting a 15-second mini, but doing the daily crossword fast seems like chugging fine wine straight from the bottle.  I wonder if the speed solvers are also speedy readers.  I am a slow reader who will stare off into space pondering an interesting turn of phrase or a sharp observation.  My whole family is like this.  Maybe it's genetic.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
Why so much judgment?

I've tried to reply about this twice below, but both attempts were unsuccessful

Traditional Polish weddings and baptisms take place at the altar ü§∑

@Andrzej

I'm the same with street to home clothes and shoes. I come home and get comfy.

Recently I was watching a show about a family and they all kept their shoes on all day and night...   had them on the SOFA and all. I was so grossed out by it, I could barely keep watching.

I thought of RAMSeY too at first . Then I came to the ALTAR and all became clear.

@HeathieJ

Most Poles change into tracksuit pants at home, usually well worn, baggy ones ü§£

If an American walked in on a typical Polish family in house clothes, they'd think hobos were squatting there üòÜ

It's 8 AM here but already very warm, so I'm sitting on my coin-free sofa in comfy, *very* short cotton shorts rather than tracksuit pants ü§™. I'm actually nonchalant enough to go for walks around the housing estate with Jorge the Lab dressed like that üòÉ. My wife on the other hand always changes into street clothes even for the shortest walks with him.

@Andrzej
Alter is a word, a verb, meaning to change. It is not a noun (ie not a thing)

@DocP

Sure, but *an* alter, especially as a place for weddings and baptisms, isn't.

@Andrzej We Brits (and Americans) also put our suitcases on clean hotel beds.

Whenever my non-British wife sees this on TV she freaks out.

I long ago learned to change into inside clothes whenever entering the house - I'm sure it makes me go outside less though, what with the faff of getting changed every time. I suspect if left to my own devices I'd revert back to wearing outside clothes inside - not on the bed though. And shoes off for sure.

Although, for the record, I do think it's mainly psychological. Most carpets harbour many more bugs than the sole of a shoe ever will*...

*no sources cited
@Andrzej In Catholic churches the baptismal font is in the same area as the altar, usually positioned a bit to the side. Definitely NOT on opposite ends of the church.

@Tim

I used to put my suitcase on hotel beds  right away when the room had two queen beds instead of a king. Then I read that when first entering the room, one should put luggage in the bathtub or shower until a thorough check for bedbugs has been done.  I stopped putting suitcases on the bed and started using the luggage rack.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
Not at the Catholic church I go to.  The font is at the back.

@Andrzej. I‚Äôve always thought that cabbage meaning money comes from the idea that cabbage is green and paperlike, as is US currency. PS: I always enjoy your good will and insights.  I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôve stuck around.

@Andrzej

Trust me, I would fit right in on this one!!  üòÇ  My husband wouldn't but me, I'm not in the door 5 minutes before I'm in my well worn comfies!  Happiness!!

@Andrzej

I saw the (controversial) Iranian movie "Seed of the Sacred Fig" recently, and it showed the husband returning home from his government job and taking off his work clothes and putting on his home clothes.  It served a symbolic meaning for the film, but I also thought that it seemed like such a civilized thing to do.
The same for the custom of taking off your street shoes (and putting on house slippers). 
I've tried to adopt these practices, but it doesn't come naturally to an American.

@Andrzej et alia/alii

Welp...I have never changed clothes after coming home from school, work, or shopping.  Waste of time.  Onerous task.  Requiring more clothing than I had!
After heavy work in the garden/orchard or on the tractor, especially on hot days, I did leave my dirty/sweaty yardwork clothes in the mud room, and nowadays I change after walking in the murderous heat/humidity, (because the clothes are wet!)  but I am not about to spend my time putting on/taking off clothes otherwise.  Sheesh.
Andrzej, yes-- Americans are uncouth peasants.  Oops!

@Andrzej
Once you walk around the housing estate in your home  clothes, don‚Äôt they become outdoor clothes?

@Graphic

@Becky 

Some people claim that colors on opposite sides of the color wheel, assuming equal intensities, present too much contrast, and therefore "clash."

But the whole concept is a matter of taste, and often a matter of the fashions of a given time. Color combinations that were disparaged in 1962, for instance, were everywhere five years later.

@Andrzej
Just about any church that does baptism by immersion is not done at the altar (mostly because many Baptist or nondenominational churches don‚Äôt have altars anymore). It‚Äôs often done in a horse trough or portable pool sometimes in the middle of the ‚Äústage‚Äù or off to the side. And a font is often in the back of the church or also off to the side. It‚Äôs varied enough that IMO, baptism should not have been in the clue.

This discussion reminds me of the beautiful, late-Mediaeval Baptistry in Florence, a separate building for performing the baptismal rites.
